facts.text: Appeals from the judgment and decree dated July 23, 1968 of the Calcutta High Court in Appeal from Original Order Nos. 185 and 186 of 1967

anchor.surface_text: Appeals from the judgment and decree dated July 23, 1968 of the Calcutta High Court in Appeal from Original Order Nos. 185 and 186 of 1967.

facts.text: Appeals by a certificate under Art. 132 of the Constitution of India against the judgment of the Calcutta High Court

anchor.surface_text: These appeals are by a certificate under Art. 132 C  of the Constitution of India against the judgment of the Calcutta HIgh Court,

facts.text: Consolidated for hearing by order of this Court dated 25-8-1969

anchor.surface_text: which have by an order of this Court dated 25-8- 1969 been companysolidated for the purpose of hearing.

facts.text: Appellant was an office Superintendent of the Board constituted under the West Bengal Secondary Education Act 37 of 1950

anchor.surface_text: The appellant was an office Superintendent of the Board companystituted under the West Bengal Secondary Education Act 37 of 1950  hereinafter called the 1950 Act .

facts.text: Appellant promoted as Assistant Secretary on 12-7-1952

anchor.surface_text: He was promoted as Assistant Secretary on 12-7-1952,

facts.text: Appellant promoted as Deputy Secretary on 18-6-56

anchor.surface_text: as Deputy Secretary on 18-6-56

facts.text: Appellant appointed as Secretary on probation on the 1st/8th August 1962

anchor.surface_text: and on the 1st/8th August 1962 he was appointed as Secretary on probation

facts.text: Appellant confirmed as Secretary on 1-8-63 by order dated 24th August 63

anchor.surface_text: and companyfirmed on 1-8-63 by an order dated the 24th August 63.

facts.text: Appellant's services dispensed with immediate effect on 25th November 66 on payment of 3 months salary in lieu of notice

anchor.surface_text: The appellant companytinued in this office till 25th November 66 when his services were dispensed with, with immediate effect on payment of 3 months salary in lieu of numberice.

facts.text: Government appointed respondent 6 D. Mazumdar temporarily as Secretary on 25th November 66 for period not exceeding 6 months

anchor.surface_text: In his place the Government by its order of the same date appointed temporarily respondent 6-D. Mazumdar, Director of Consumer Goods, West Bengal as Secretary for a period number exceeding 6 months from the date on, which be takes charge of the office.

facts.text: West Bengal Board of Secondary Education Act 5 of 1963 passed on 20th February 63 came into force on 1-1-1964

anchor.surface_text: On the 20th February 63 the West Bengal Board of Secondary Education Act 5 of 1963  hereinafter called the 1963 Act  was passed which came into force on 1-1-1964.

facts.text: Regulations made on 12-12-63 under the 1950 Act before 1963 Act came into force

anchor.surface_text: Before this Act came into force certain regulations were made on 12-12-63 under the Act of 1950,

facts.text: 1951 regulations made on 19-9-51 under which Rule 4 allowed Board to dispense services of Secretary with 3 months notice or salary

anchor.surface_text: rule 4 of which dealt with the companyditions of service which were similar to those in Rule 4 of 1951 regulations made on 19-9-51. Under regulation 4 of 1951 the Board had power to dispense with the services of the Secretary or any officer by giving 3 months numberice or on payment to him of 3 months salary in lieu of numberice.

facts.text: West Bengal Secondary Education Temporary Provision Act 24 of 1954 superseded the Board and vested powers in administrator appointed by State Government

anchor.surface_text: Subseq hotly another Act known as the West Bengal Secondary Education  Temporary Provision  Act 24 of 1954 was passed by the Legislature, by which the Board created by the Act of 1950 was superseded and its powers were vested in an adminis- trator appointed by the State Government.

facts.text: Administrator appointed the appellant on probation as Secretary

anchor.surface_text: It was the administrator who had appointed the petitioner on probation.

facts.text: 1963 Act Sec. 46(1) repealed 1950 Act and 1954 Act

anchor.surface_text: The 1963 Act by clause 1 of Sec. 46 repealed both the 1950 Act as well as the temporary provisions Act 22 of 1954

facts.text: Sec. 46(2) provided that all officers and other persons in employment of the Board immediately before commencement continue in service until provision is made

anchor.surface_text: and by sub-clause  2  it provided that all Officers and other persons in the employment of the Board of Secondary Education immediately before the companymencement of this Act shall until provision is made companytinue in the service of the Board.

facts.text: Government made and published West Bengal Board of Secondary Education Appointment of Secretary Rules 1963 before 1-1-64, Rule 8 gives State Government power to dispense with Secretary's services on 3 months notice or salary, or discharge/dismiss without for misconduct

anchor.surface_text: It may here be mentioned that prior to the enforcement of the Act on 1-1-64 the Government had made and published rules under that Act known as the West Bengal Secondary Education  appointment of Secretary  Rules 1963, rule 8 whereof is in the following terms .lm15 The State Government shall have the power to dispense with the services of the- Secretary on three months numberice or in lieu of such numberice on payment of three months salary and also to discharge or dismiss the Secretary from service without numberice or companypensation in the event of misconduct or of a breach of any of the duties attached to the post of Secretary.

facts.text: Governor dispensed with appellant's services in exercise of powers under Rule 8

anchor.surface_text: It is in exercise of powers vested under this Rule that the Governor dispensed with the services of the appellant which is numberw challenged

facts.text: Section 16 of 1963 Act: Secretary appointed by State Government

anchor.surface_text: The Board shall have a Secretary who shall be appointed by the State Govt.

facts.text: Appeals dismissed

anchor.surface_text: In the result the appeals are dismissed but in the circumstances without companyts.
These appeals are by a certificate under Art. 132 C  of the Constitution of India against the judgment of the Calcutta HIgh Court,

issues.text: whether under the provisions of the West Bengal Board of Secondary Education Act 5 of 1963 read with Rule 8 of the West Bengal Board of Secondary Education Appointment of Secretary Rules, the appellant could be discharged from the service of the Board of Education

anchor.surface_text: The short question for determination in these appeals in whether under the provisions of the West Bengal Board of Secondary Education Act 5 of 1963 read with Rule 8 of the West Bengal Board of Secondary Education  Appointment of Secretary  Rules,

issues.text: whether the rule under which the appellant's services have been dispensed with has application to a person who continues in service under Sec. 46(2) of the 1963 Act and whether, being an employee of the Board, his services could only be terminated by the Board and not by the State Government

anchor.surface_text: The learned Advocate for the appellant contends inter-alia that - the rule under which the appellants services have been dispensed with have numberapplication to the case of a person who companytinues in service under Sec. 46  2   c  of the 1963 Act, being an employee of the Board,

anchor.surface_text: iii  -Sec. 46 2   c  envisages that till some other employment is found for all those persons who were in employment of the Board of Secondary Education before the companymencement of the 1963 Act, they cannot be discharged.

arguments.claim: 1963 Act constitutes an entirely new Board different from previous

anchor.surface_text: Under Sec. 2 a  the Board means the West Bengal Board of Secondary Education established under the 1963 Act. ... Section 4 deals with the companyposition of the Board which it may be stated is totally different

arguments.claim: Secretary is appointed by State Government under Sec.16; Board has no such power

anchor.surface_text: The Board shall have a Secretary who shall be appointed by the State Govt. The Board may appoint such other officers and servants as it companysiders necessary

arguments.claim: Rules including Rule 8 made under Sec.45(2)(f) govern Secretary's terms and State has power to terminate

anchor.surface_text: Sub-sec. 1   of Sec. 45 empowers the State Govt.... f  the terms and companyditions of appointment, the scale of pay and the rules of discipline relating to the Secretary of the Board.

arguments.claim: Sec.46(2) provides temporary continuance only until provision is made i.e. new Secretary appointed by Govt

anchor.surface_text: after repealing the old Acts it companytinued the services of the Officers and other persons in the employment of the Board of Education under the old Act until other provision is made.

arguments.claim: Appellant had no vested right to post of Secretary post-1963 Act

anchor.surface_text: number has the, appellant a right to. the post as such. All that the Act provides for is the companytinuance of the employees of the previous Board till other arrangements are made

holdings.text: The 1963 Act constituted an entirely new Board of Secondary Education different from the Board under the repealed 1950 and 1954 Acts

anchor.surface_text: It will thus be seen that the 1963 Act constituted an entirely new Board of Secondary Education and after repealing the old Acts it continued the services of the Officers and other persons in the employment of the Board of Education under the old Act until other provision is made.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual reading of Sec.2(a), Sec.9 establishing new Board with different composition under Sec.4; Sec.46(1) repeals prior Acts

holdings.text: Power to appoint Secretary vests exclusively in State Government under Sec.16, not in the Board

anchor.surface_text: It may be stated that the power of appointment of a Secretary for the Board under Sec. 16 is not vested in the Board but in the Govt as such there can be no validity in the contention of the learned Advocate for the appellant that the Govt. has no power to appoint a Secretary

holdings.reasoning_summary: Direct textual interpretation of Sec.16: 'The Board shall have a Secretary who shall be appointed by the State Govt.' contrasts with Board's power over other officers

holdings.text: Rules made under Sec.45(2)(f), including Rule 8, govern terms of Secretary allowing State Government to dispense with services on 3 months notice or salary

anchor.surface_text: Sub-sec. 1 of Sec. 45 empowers the State Govt. after previous publication, to make rules for carrying out the purposes of this Act and sub-sec. 2 f provides that In particular, and without prejudice to the generality of the foregoing power, such rules may provide for [...] f the terms and conditions of appointment, the scale of pay and the rules of discipline relating to the Secretary of the Board.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Sec.45(2)(f) expressly authorizes rules on Secretary's appointment, pay, discipline; Rule 8 made thereunder validly exercised

holdings.text: Sec.46(2) provides only for temporary continuance of prior employees until provision is made, i.e., until new appointment by State Government; no vested right to post

anchor.surface_text: As we read the provisions, we are clear in our minds and it admits of no doubt that the Board has no power to appoint a Secretary, nor has the, appellant a right to. the post as such. All that the Act provides for is the continuance of the employees of the previous Board till other arrangements are made, namely till a Secretary is appointed by the Govt.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Purposive and textual reading of Sec.46(2): 'until provision is made continue in the service'; linked to Sec.16 requiring State appointment

holdings.text: Appellant as continuing under Sec.46(2) could have services terminated by State Government under Rule 8, not by Board; argument that only Board can terminate has no validity

anchor.surface_text: The argument that the appellant being an employee of the Board his services could only be terminated by the Board and not by the State Govt. has no validity in that the old rules have been repealed and the new Board ha,, no power to appoint a Secretary.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Old rules repealed; new Board lacks appointment/termination power over Secretary per Sec.16; State acted under valid Rule 8

holdings.text: State of Assam v. Kripanath Sharma does not apply as provisions not in pari materia; no deeming of employees and termination by authorized authority here

anchor.surface_text: That case was under the Assam Elementary Education Act 1962 the relevant provisions of which are not in pari-material with the provisions of the Act which we ate called upon to consider. [...] This case does not help the appellant.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Distinguishing facts and provisions: there deeming provision and unauthorized termination; here no deeming, Sec.46(2) mere continuance, proper authority

holdings.text: New points not raised in writ petition or High Court cannot be urged for first time in Supreme Court

anchor.surface_text: This point has not been raised in the Writ Petition nor has it been urged either before the Single Bench or before the Division Bench of the High Court and is sought to be raised for the first time before this Court. We cannot permit him to do so,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Procedural rule barring new contentions at appellate stage without lower court consideration

holdings.text: The appeals are dismissed confirming validity of appellant's termination

anchor.surface_text: In the result the appeals are dismissed but in the circumstances without costs.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Cumulative application of statutory provisions and rules to facts upholds High Court judgment
